results.title: Teach Tiwi proper way
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Barker, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The elders of the Tiwi people on Melville and Bathurst Islands have been concerned that their traditional way of life will die out with this generation and so they have instigated bilingual, bicultural education in the local schools, so that the children now learn the Tiwi language and cultural tradition as well as English.

results.title: Teach me what?
results.creator_credit: Peter Johnson, Film Australia, Camfilm Productions and David E. Barrow
results.brief_description:
Shows the Army Apprentices School as an institution that trains boys for a career in the Army as tradesmen. Includes a variety of trades open to young men, and shows extra-curricular activities and the opportunity for sport. The story endeavours to humanise the Army and to dispel some preconceptions.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Teach me to dance
results.creator_credit: Vladimir Valenta, ONF | NFB and Anne Wheeler
results.brief_description: Lesia convinces her English-Canadian friend Sarah to perform a Ukrainian dance with her as part of their school’s Christmas pageant. However, Sarah’s father objects. Angry at the growing number of Ukrainian settlers, he will not allow his daughter to do the Ukrainian dance with Lesia. But in spite of the prejudices of their parents, the girls’ friendship remains strong, and they meet in Sarah’s barn to celebrate Christmas Day together. Award: Milan. Story and screenplay by Myrna Kostash. Suitable for upper primary and middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Teach me how I can do it myself: the Montessori Method in the Netherlands (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jack Apon, Nederlandse Onderwijs Film and Theo Van Haren Noman
results.brief_description: Dr. Maria Montessori’s original contribution to the psychology of education has left a mark on present day schooling throughout the world. This film aims to give an impression of the methods she worked out for infant and primary school, based upon the child’s genuine needs.

results.title: Tea growing in Assam
results.brief_description: Shows the stages in the cultivation and processing of tea. A map shows the tea-producing areas of the world; Assam is taken as an example and scenes show workers planting out the young seeds and plants. Pruning, weeding and plucking are seen, and the factory processes described by animated diagrams. From Assam the tea goes to Calcutta and London, where it is blended with tea from other countries.

results.title: Tea from Nyasaland
results.brief_description: A complete story of the growth, cultivation, and preparation of tea. The plantation sequences, shot in Nyasaland, East Equatorial Africa, show how the tea plant is grown and cultivated, how the leaves of the tea plant are picked, fermented, dried, cut and packed for bulk shipment. The London sequences show how the bulk tea is received, sampled, blended, and packed for retail to the consumer.

results.title: Tea for three
results.creator_credit: Jane Keneally, AFTRS and Anthony Johnsen
results.brief_description: Three gangsters, one teapot, all of them know the intricacies of how the tea should be poured, the way the kettle should be turned, the sequence of ingredients and they’ll be damned if the process isn’t followed properly. Tarantino meets high tea in this short and wicked drama. Cast includes Lech Mackiewicz, Anthony Johnson and Jed Kurzel. Contains some course language.

results.title: Tea for Elsa
results.creator_credit: Counterpoint Films and Samuel J Koplowicz
results.brief_description: Contrasts the tense excitement of a museum robbery with the monotonous routine of a charlady to make a statement about apathy and non-involvement.

results.title: Tea Cult of Japan = Cha-no-yu
results.brief_description: The Tea Ceremony is an ancient cultural tradition in Japan. It has an almost religious significance, and is approached in this manner by those who take part in it. Traces the history of the Ceremony, its ritual and demonstrates its practice.
results.description: The Tea Ceremony is an ancient cultural tradition in Japan. It has an almost religious significance, and is approached in this manner by those who take part in it. Traces the history of the Ceremony, its ritual and demonstrates its practice.
